section.p: Translations are defined at different levels in Design Studio, creating a sort of hierarchy. The translation defined at the class level also exists at the dataset level and at the page level. Translations can be overwritten at each level.

section.title: Example 1 (most common): The translations are only defined at the Class level

ul.li: The translation of the attribute A is defined at the Class level.
The translation is left empty at the Dataset level.
The user drags and drops the class attribute A of the dataset into the page. The system retrieves the Class level translation.

section.title: Example 2: Create translation at the Page level

ul.li: The translation of the attribute A is defined at the Class level.
The translation is left empty at the Dataset level.
The user drags and drops the class attribute A of the dataset into the page. The system retrieves the Class level translation.
The user creates a translation at the Page level.

section.title: Example 3: Overwrite at the Dataset level

ul.li: The translation of the attribute A is defined at the Class level.
The translation is overwritten at the Dataset level.
The user drags and drops the class attribute A of the dataset into the page. The system retrieves the Dataset level translation.

section.title: Example 4: Overwrite at the Dataset level and at the Page level

ul.li: The translation of the attribute A is defined at the Class level.
The translation is overwritten at the Dataset level.
The user drags and drops the class attribute A of the dataset into the page. The system retrieves the Dataset level translation.
The user creates a translation at the Page level.
